advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #6</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"With the Alice, change the level without changing the computer"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (APRIL 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Once upon a time, the future"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1983 BADGES</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMMERCIAL PAMPHLET - PAGE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to Richard Rogers </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ISAAC ASIMOV #2 </strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSERT - RECTO</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US DEALER ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Until now, parents interested in expanding their children's educational experience, turned to expensive encyclopedias. With the advent of the PET personal computer a new avenue of visual learning is now available for your youngsters for as low as $595....<br><br> ... Your youngster will think he's playing, you'll know he's learning with the remarkable PET... </font><br><br> At the time, parents often thought a personal computer could help their youngsters learning, but 80% of the home computers sold in the 80's was used only for playing. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to Douglas Reedy</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD (JULY, 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Eric Buczynski for this advert</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Kaypro, it runs" ! <br><br> "Kaypro, the computer which can be carried away" <br><br> "Elected Transportable Computer of the year"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">... One of the results is our new identity and our new product: the Intersystems DPS-1. An IEEE S-100 compatible mainframe with features that live up to its look. <i>Dependable</i> operation to 4 Mhz. Twenty-card capacity, a modular power supply. And something no one else has: built-in break points to give you a faster, more powerful tool for testing software as well as hardware...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ARGENTINIAN ADVERT </strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.speccy.org/czarg/" target="_blank">CZARG</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href=§http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage§>Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It's him" <br><br> This is not an Apple official advert, but from french distributor called Micro Informatique Diffusion (MID)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LISA ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>He is rich (enough to buy a LISA !), he is relaxed... He is the typical advertising executive of the 80's.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INTERACTION NEWSLETTER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Three issues of this 'Newsletter Detroit Interact Group' were published during the first semester of 1980</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST AD.</strong></font><br><blockquote>January 1983<br><br> Telcon needed customers payments before manufacturing the systems:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Upon receipt of your check, we will forward an end-user agreement. Allow 6 to 8 weeks for delivery of the units. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #1 (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Electron, the personal micro which has talents of a pro"...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD (AUG. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.description: Gemini was the company that rose from the ashes of the demise of Nascom (at the same time that Lucas bought the Nascom name). The computer was thus designed by the people who initially set up Nascom. In fact, it tooke advantage of some of the later ideas floated around the Nascom 2. Although it was available as a series of single boards and plug-in modules for the 'kit' enthusiasts, it was mainly sold as a complete unit with typewriter style keyboard and dual floppy disc drive. 64 KB of user RAM was provided as standard and the computer came with two Z80A processors, one driving the video, the other doing all the rest. Software provided included a CP/M operating system and a 24 KB Microsoft BASIC interpreter
computer.ports: 2 x Parallel Centronics, Serial RS232, Cassette tape, Light Pen
